ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Knowledgeable and helpful TA!
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho was the only teaching assistant for this class.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly was always very organized and communicative. I found it helpful that she held review sessions before each midterm to go over any questions students had prior to the exam. I do not think there is anything that must be improved upon.

Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly was very responsive over email and helpful in running great review sections before the midterms. I didn't work with her too much during the semester but she was always patient and helpful when I did have questions.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  The pre-exam preparation meetings were very useful, and Kelly did well at directing those discussions.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  We didn't really interact with the TA much. As far as I know she did not hold office hours.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Before exam review sessions were really helpful!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Having no previous experience with wetlands, I learned a lot from this course and Professor Friedenburg. Her powerpoints were helpful, and I thought her selection of the Keddy book was great. It's definitely one of the most engaging textbooks I've ever read. She is also quite responsive to feedback, and overall a good instructor. I enjoyed her class!

This class was terrific and challenging. Kealoha covers a lot of material in great detail and the reading was quite dense, but I learned so much about wetlands. Lectures were always fascinating and I thought Kealoha did a great job of bringing in current events applying what we'd learned, and the class was very well structured. All of the lectures from the first portion of the course prepared us to get a lot out of the more applied topics towards the end of the semester.

The workload was heavier than most classes, particularly the questions due before each class. However, it was a pleasant class and I learned a lot, despite sometimes feeling frustrated with how the class was taught.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Wetlands in the News--Field Trips--some of the more interesting papers were the one on pharmaceuticals, the climate change test pods, and the ones on invasives.
I enjoyed learning about wetlands from both ecological and management perspectives throughout the course.

I thought the best aspects of the course related to the course discussions on the readings and the professor's personal experiences with wetland management. I felt that these sessions during the class provided particular insights into wetlands management and allowed the students to discuss their personal experiences with wetlands management. I found these conversations to be helpful in making the application of the readings more accessible.

I thought the lectures were the best part of the course. Kealoha creates a very balanced course that is scientifically rigorous but still approachable for students with less of an ecology background. I always enjoyed walking through the experimental design and results of each of the articles we'd read in detail and getting a stronger understanding of how the trends we observe in wetlands are studied.

The field trips were great -- it's so useful to be able to see examples of processes and patterns we discussed. Also, the discussion-based format of class meetings worked very well, especially since we had a couple of students with field experience who were able to offer their perspectives.
Field trips and when the instructor was talking about her expertise/research
Learning about wetlands!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It might be nice to have more breakout discussion groups, or have someone assigned to lead the discussion each week in tandem with Kealoha. Just suggestions though, overall the structure is good!
I would have enjoyed if field trips were built into the course time, as having more of them would have provided a deeper understanding of the concepts we discussed in class.

I have one major recommendation for the course, which relates to the way it was structured. As mentioned above, I found the discussion sections to be particularly helpful; however, sometimes they seemed a bit rushed. It is clear that the professor recognized the importance of these discussions as she always made a point to get to them. My recommendation would be to split the two class meetings per week between lecture and discussion. This would require doubling the topics covered per class period; however, I think it would make the discussion sessions more productive. Furthermore, if the discussion questions were due on Thursday and based on the lectures from Tuesday, it might be a more effective relationship between lectures, readings, and discussions.
Submitting discussion questions prior to class meetings can be useful, but I often found myself reading more to generate questions for the sake of the assignment than reading for comprehension.

I think the course could be improved if the requirement for discussion questions was changed from 5 to 3. I found myself paying less attention to the substance of the readings as I was reading them because I was so focused on thinking up relevant questions. As a result I feel like I didn't absorb as much of the material. I do think coming up with questions is helpful, but 5 per student seemed like a lot. We rarely addressed more than 2 or 3 in class.
Kealoha is an incredibly accomplished and smart woman! Sometimes she would apologize for running late or other minor things when in reality she really got this!
Teaching method and general lecturing could be improved. Sometimes the class could be more engaging, rather than just regurgitating the papers we read.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Please see response to Question 18.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It was very useful to have an ecology course focused on aquatic resources, particularly for someone interested in coastal ecosystems.

This course was effective in providing a strong foundation to wetland ecology, which was important for my knowledge and skill set. I did not have any prior experience with ecology and so some of the basic principles we covered were useful for me. Overall the content of this course was related to my overall program goals by explaining the ecological concepts behind constructed wetlands and engineered natural systems.
Fits well with wetland/hydrology/chemistry theme, I just wished there would be more courses offered in this area.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: In order to gain a deeper understanding of ecology as it pertains to wetlands, and to provide me with a wider perspective on the management of coastal ecosystems.
Please see answer to Question 20.

I was interested in wetland mitigation programs and payment for ecosystem services schemes around wetlands. This course was a great introduction into how wetland ecosystems function and how that informs how they are managed and regulated.
General interest in wetlands, and because of potential professional applications.
I'm an hydrologist and this was one of the few courses in this field. Additionally I developed a special interest in wetlands during my first year at FES.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I learned a great deal about wetlands, their ecology, unanswered questions, and how they are currently managed.
Yes, the knowledge and skills I gained from this course were in line with my expectations.
This course absolutely surpassed my expectations. I learned so much and greatly enjoyed the semester.
Yes -- I think we got a good comprehensive view of major drivers of wetland ecology, and still managed to address ongoing questions and issues.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I had a study group with three other students for the midterms and the final and it was extremely helpful to talk through the study guides as a group. I would make study sheets myself based off of the lecture notes and my notes on the readings beforehand, and then practice answering questions out loud with the group. We always brought up points I'd missed or clarified concepts I was confused about together.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared to put a lot of time into the reading. There will be detailed questions on the examination and in-class discussion is important.
Overall pretty good class. Would recommend with some caveats about teaching style.
